instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: Hi, have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with some super weird problems I?ve never seen before. I got it having a short on PPBUS. This was cleared after removing MOSFET <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> which cleared the short. Replaced it with a donor and as soon as I gave it power it got very hot and PPBUS was shorted again. I checked out <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and found it outputting 12V to a 5V line. Replaced it and the mosfet with another donor and no more short on PPBUS. Still won?t boot though. <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> has an Enable of 3.02V instead of normal 3.3 but it does have the supply of 12V. Is the low Enable a Problem? Anyone got any tips? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: Theonly thing getting a little hot is the PCH

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Welcome to the forum!

Do you really think 3.02V is too low?
If you read many posts, should know that many times we talk about 3V when reffer to 3.3V power rails, or signals.
In fact 2.1V is the min threshold for high logic level (1L); as 0.8V es the max threshold for low logic level (0L).
0.8V-2.1V is a prohibited range, where a logic level is no guaranteed to be recognized correctly.

Burnt <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> could mean the board is trash now.
Overvoltages on 3V3 and 5V rails is almost letal...
After all, do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and Magsafe light?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Hi, thanks for your reply! 

Yeah, 3.02 should be fine I just wanted to verify. I have a Magsafe Light and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 40mV so basically 0. Any idea on what to do next?

Thanks!

threads.message:
Looks like bad <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> for me; or incorrect solders.
Post first diode mode (red probe at ground) on pins 13, 22, 29; no power, of course.

Pin 13 - .47
Pin 22 - OL
Pin 29 - .45


Should I just order up a new <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> Chip? I mean we don't fully know if the chip off of the donor board was any good...

threads.message:
Also check diode mode at L7220/60.
If good, change <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.

Really strange to got bad one from scrap.
Don't you have more donor boards in the pile?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, because of burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>.
Looks like scrap board now.

If have time, you can remove <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>; then check diode mode again.
Do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>...

Out of pure curiosity: what would happen if I powered it up with those missing parts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
"Out of pure curiosity: what would happen if I powered it up with those missing parts?"
I could tell you try and see ;).
But I'm afraid you can come and kill me, after lockdown time finished :mad:.
Seriously, do not try any of these options...

Leaving <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> with Gate floating on air is a really bad idea.

Remaining short after L7260 could mean damaged SMC, PCH, or CPU.
You can try injecting voltage there and check if something gets hot.
Remove CPU heatsink for test.
Start with 1V and do not exceed 4V; leave amp limit at max on the PSU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: Ah got ya, just wanted to know. Would never try that... I did find something curious though. On the PCH itself there is a tiny Capacitor. When I put my meter in continuity if beeps on both sides of that cap. On my donor it doesn't. Is that relevant? I'll get a new bench PSU (me idiot killed mine yesterday) and try injecting Volatge

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Beeps is not same as short.
Some power rails have low value as normal; and beeps for this reason.
If you get much higher value on identical board, this is sign of failure.
However, that cap is connected on the same power rails with many other external components; not sufficient reason to doubt about PCH (yet).
Inject voltage and check which component heats...

<CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR>/93 easy to solder too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
UPDTAE:

I got my new Bench PSU and after going through a can of freeze spray with a draw of 1A I found <CAPACITOR>C7293</CAPACITOR> to heat up. Removed it alongside <CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR> and now it draws .001A at 1V and the diode mode on L7260 changed to .108

Any better?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Resolder components and check diode mode again; do NOT power yet.
If still low value, <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> is probably burnt.
I recommend you to directly change both <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: Oof. more issues! No fan spin or anything. But then I noticed a big fat burn mark on <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR>. Replaced it but now the green light comes on for about 5 seconds before turning off and with freeze spray I can see <RESISTOR>R6902</RESISTOR> immediately heating up. Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Just skipped quickly through this thread, but why are you putting time and effort into a board that had 12V on the 5V rail? Not want to rain on your parade, but the chance of a dead PCH/CPU is pretty much 100% here. 

<RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> getting hot will be a short on 3V42 or on the input of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>. I'm going for 3V42 short that traces back to the PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
Yeah. Probably financially an absolute waste of time. But I just wanna get this fixed no matter what. Yeah I?m weird.


Replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> but that helped nothing. Any way I can find out if the PCH is actually bad? I mean if I knew it was I?d replace it but I?m not sure if it is...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: is 3V42 shorted? If yes inject 3V into that rail and see if PCH heats up. If it does then you should really stop there as there is probably even more damage beyond the PCH too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: It heats up a bit, yeah... Should I order a new PCH from AliExpress or get one from a donor board and attempt a replacement? Never replaced a PCH before though I did a CPU upgrade on an 09 white MacBooms so it shouldn't be much dirfferent...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message: I bet you have more damage than PCH only...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> weird power problems
threads.message:
0.76mm or 0.45mm balls, that is the difference. You can order it new or get it from a dead board, but you maybe it will be better to fix the dead board you are pulling it from than this thing.

Seriously, this will be a total waste of time and money, this thing is done.
